repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
why is this needed? reviewing df2293e176141db3fd2b421119560e32034e42b0 , 727d619cc9b888638bb89d2487e701f8f1afe83b does not clarify.

Users won't have these defined, so CI shouldn't need to define them...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -37,6 +37,10 @@ env:
                    -DDEPS_PREFIX=$DEPS_BUILD_DIR/usr
                    -DMIN_LOG_LEVEL=3"
     - DEPS_CMAKE_FLAGS="-DUSE_BUNDLED_GPERF=OFF"
+    # Additional CMake flags for 32-bit builds.
+    - CMAKE_FLAGS_32BIT="-DCMAKE_SYSTEM_LIBRARY_PATH=/lib32:/usr/lib32:/usr/local/lib32
+                         -DCMAKE_IGNORE_PATH=/lib:/usr/lib:/usr/local/lib
+                         -DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE=$TRAVIS_BUILD_DIR/cmake/i386-linux-gnu.toolchain.cmake"

comment_data.body: does this still need to be a cmake option? why not let `find_package(LibACL)` decide it?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -98,6 +98,13 @@ else()
   option(ENABLE_LTO "enable link time optimization" ON)
 endif()
 
+if(CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME MATCHES "OpenBSD|NetBSD|Windows")
+  message(STATUS "skipping libacl on this sytem: ${CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME}")
+  option(ENABLE_LIBACL "enable libacl" OFF)
+else()
+  option(ENABLE_LIBACL "enabled libacl" ON)
+endif()

comment_data.body: I just followed it because `libintl` and `libiconv` are cmake option without automatic detection.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -98,6 +98,13 @@ else()
   option(ENABLE_LTO "enable link time optimization" ON)
 endif()
 
+if(CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME MATCHES "OpenBSD|NetBSD|Windows")
+  message(STATUS "skipping libacl on this sytem: ${CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME}")
+  option(ENABLE_LIBACL "enable libacl" OFF)
+else()
+  option(ENABLE_LIBACL "enabled libacl" ON)
+endif()

comment_data.body:
ok. `libintl` and `libiconv` are that way because of history (Windows support). We will remove those options once we're confident that they are always working on Windows.

In the case of ACL, there's no reason to make it an option: either we find the library or we don't.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -98,6 +98,13 @@ else()
   option(ENABLE_LTO "enable link time optimization" ON)
 endif()
 
+if(CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME MATCHES "OpenBSD|NetBSD|Windows")
+  message(STATUS "skipping libacl on this sytem: ${CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME}")
+  option(ENABLE_LIBACL "enable libacl" OFF)
+else()
+  option(ENABLE_LIBACL "enabled libacl" ON)
+endif()

comment_data.body: I don't know what the cause is, but in the CI environment 64bit `libacl` was used by linking and the build failed, so I needed to set it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -37,6 +37,10 @@ env:
                    -DDEPS_PREFIX=$DEPS_BUILD_DIR/usr
                    -DMIN_LOG_LEVEL=3"
     - DEPS_CMAKE_FLAGS="-DUSE_BUNDLED_GPERF=OFF"
+    # Additional CMake flags for 32-bit builds.
+    - CMAKE_FLAGS_32BIT="-DCMAKE_SYSTEM_LIBRARY_PATH=/lib32:/usr/lib32:/usr/local/lib32
+                         -DCMAKE_IGNORE_PATH=/lib:/usr/lib:/usr/local/lib
+                         -DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE=$TRAVIS_BUILD_DIR/cmake/i386-linux-gnu.toolchain.cmake"

comment_data.body:
This shouldn't be needed. We used to have something like this, but removed it recently: 3d3c783fead3dc328ede3ccd0fb7b3befcad191a . And our `gcc-32bit` job is specifying `CMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE` already.

Note also that 3d3c783fead3dc328ede3ccd0fb7b3befcad191a mentions that `CMAKE_SYSTEM_LIBRARY_PATH` is semicolon-separated and "shouldn't be used" (maybe cmake docs explain).

maybe @blueyed has insight
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -37,6 +37,10 @@ env:
                    -DDEPS_PREFIX=$DEPS_BUILD_DIR/usr
                    -DMIN_LOG_LEVEL=3"
     - DEPS_CMAKE_FLAGS="-DUSE_BUNDLED_GPERF=OFF"
+    # Additional CMake flags for 32-bit builds.
+    - CMAKE_FLAGS_32BIT="-DCMAKE_SYSTEM_LIBRARY_PATH=/lib32:/usr/lib32:/usr/local/lib32
+                         -DCMAKE_IGNORE_PATH=/lib:/usr/lib:/usr/local/lib
+                         -DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE=$TRAVIS_BUILD_DIR/cmake/i386-linux-gnu.toolchain.cmake"

comment_regular_data.body:
Leak is being reported in various tests (always from `<unknown module>`):

```
= =================================================================
= ==16110==ERROR: LeakSanitizer: detected memory leaks
= 
= Direct leak of 142 byte(s) in 6 object(s) allocated from:
=     #0 0x50b068 in malloc (/home/travis/build/neovim/neovim/build/bin/nvim+0x50b068)
=     #1 0x1e14449 in uv__strdup /home/travis/nvim-deps/build/src/libuv/src/uv-common.c:57
=     #2 0x65206d6574737972  (<unknown module>)
= 
= SUMMARY: AddressSanitizer: 142 byte(s) leaked in 6 allocation(s).
=====================================================================================================
test/helpers.lua:152: assertion failed!
stack traceback:
	test/helpers.lua:152: in function 'check_logs'
```

https://travis-ci.org/neovim/neovim/jobs/552662869#L1656-L1658

```
ERROR 2019-07-01T08:46:23.866 11868 u_write_undo:1111: failed set permset to entry: No data available
ERROR 2019-07-01T08:46:23.866 11868 u_write_undo:1111: failed set permset to entry: Success
ERROR 2019-07-01T08:46:23.866 11868 u_write_undo:1111: failed set permset to entry: Success
```

According to `acl_set_permset(3)`, it is impossible .

https://travis-ci.org/neovim/neovim/jobs/552662869#L1654-L1655

```
ERROR 2019-07-01T08:46:23.662 11865 os_get_acl:94: failed to get acl of a file: No such file or directory
ERROR 2019-07-01T08:46:23.732 11866 os_get_acl:94: failed to get acl of a file: No such file or directory
```

Is there a route for this to occur? Should I check the existence of the file?
Sorry for the delay in replying. I've been using neovim with this patch applied on a regular basis and haven't had any problems, so I don't think it's a problem to merge it.

What's the status of this? I don't believe ACLs are currently supported in Neovim?

In fact I don't even think traditional `umask` and `chmod g+s ...` are currently supported? For instance [new](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/6696ea7f103814d3d5700107546280bf50a4004a/src/nvim/os/fileio.c#L78) [path](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/6696ea7f103814d3d5700107546280bf50a4004a/src/nvim/ex_cmds.c#L1737) creations simply harcode `755` permissions.
